I'm sure this has been covered but I'm not sifting through a ton of comments.  Still, the entire purpose of copyright was to grant a temporary monopoly to the creator so that the creator could recoup any expenses incurred in the creation plus, hopefully, some profit, before expiring and releasing into the public domain the creator's works to be used, modified, built upon, or otherwise become a tool for everyone to advance art, science, etc.

The temporary copyright provided incentive to the creator to create something new and original, and its expiry provided an incentive for others to become creators themselves by using the material of those who came before them to build upon or use for inspiration.  The familiar old Newtonian quote, "If I have seen further it is by standing on the shoulders of giants" seems apropos here: Knowledge in the abstract is an accumulation by the use of what is currently known in furtherance of learning more.  We know what we know because those who came before us learned these things and passed that knowledge down.

Creation is knowledge + action.  I can build a shelving unit and make it my own style and copyright the design.  But I am far from the first to have built a shelving unit, and even my aesthetic eye was inspired at least in part by things that have inspired me.  Among other things, I am a musician, so I write music.  My style is my own, but I have been inspired by dozens if not hundreds of artists who came before me, artists I love and admire, so my music is almost by definition an amalgam of those inspirations filtered through my own creative lens.  Nothing is created in a vacuum.

Should creators benefit from their creations?  Obviously.  For my own lifetime plus 70 years?  No, that's absurd.  Not that I think my music will necessarily be anyone else's inspiration or that they would want to build upon my work, but I would not be opposed to having my work enter the pubic domain in 20 or 30 years.  I'd be fine with that.

What's more, one of the side effects of short copyright periods would be that it would motivate creators to keep creating new things if they want to keep getting paid for them.  And so art, and science, and everything else, continues to advance where now it is hopelessly stifled due to absurdly long copyrights and the even more absurd ability of copyright holders to extend that copyright when it expires.

You know what? A finite set of time may not be the best method of keeping copyrights active, particularly for digital works and media. Some works remain popular for decades, while others are difficult if not impossible to obtain through a legal sale after a few short years. Why can't we come up with a "use it or lose it" copyright law,where if a product is not given any means of a legal sale accessible to the majority of the population, it expires after a short time, like say 5-10 years, then the life + 70 rule can define an upper limit? Not only does this allow for continued protection of works as long as the copyright holder feels it is beneficial to make use of it, but when it is decided the product is no longer making money or protecting an interest, it can expire freely in a relatively short time. Of course, some loopholes might need to be investigated such as "what constitutes a product being available for sale to the majority of the population" - I could definitely see a company arguing that they have a copy of a work available in a proprietary format from the 90s that is no longer in use and therefore almost impossible for people to make use of, for example, so a definition of "readily available to the majority of the population" might need to be in order.


Someone might claim that it could be difficult to maintain something available for "sale" but it costs very little to keep a GB of data available on a cloud-based store for distribution these days. If the company does not make enough in sales to maintain that presence, the product likely would not make much more money over the life of the life+70 copyright anyway without some sort of massive revival that occurs mostly by chance.
